Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2008 07:10AM southernchick wrote: I'm with you Angie.  I knew I couldn't live with the constant worry.  So I had both sides done.  I had immediate reconstruction with expanders.  I am pleased with my results, I am about the same size as I was prior to the mastectomy.  I know a few people that had a uni-lateral and are now fighting cancer in the other side.  I totally understand never wanting to hear "you have cancer" again.
Posts.Title: masectomy - seems like this sucks rseaw22 Mandy1313

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2008 09:22AM southernchick wrote: My favorite comment I got was actually from a close friend.  When she found out I had to have a bi-lateral mastectomy she said, "Lucky you, you will have nice perky breasts and won't have to worry about sagging."  Yeah, like I couldn't just go get implants if I was so worried about that.  Like I would really choose to have cancer and have a mastectomy just so I could get "perky" breasts.  I really don't know how I didn't just go off on her.  Maybe I should have, it still bothers me that she said something that stupid.  With friends like that.........
Posts.Title: Very Angry! LisaG42 BessB

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2008 11:31PM southernchick wrote: What do you mean your surgeon won't do a bilateral unless BRCA is positive.  This is your body and your life.  You need to determine what is best for you.  Granted your doctor is supposed to help you do that, but I would definitely be seeing another doctor.  It is your decision, not his, what your course of treatment is.  He is there to guide you, not make the decisions for you.
Posts.Title: BCRA testing Keryl southernchick

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2008 09:25PM southernchick wrote: Go get your mammogram done.  Chances are great that you are fine.  But if they do find something, it would only be to your benefit to find it and take care of it.  Most women that have breast cancer caught early have a very, very good prognosis.  If you did have anything, you would want to catch it before it spreads.  Ignorance may be bliss, but action may save your life.  You don't mention that you have discovered any lumps or anything.  But I am all for doing whatever it takes to get healthy. I found my breast cancer early.  It didn't show up on mammo, but did on ultrasound.  I just passed my one year anniversary and am doing great.  I Thank God all the time that I found it before it spread.  Give yourself the same chance.
Posts.Title: I'm 40 and scared Cicilass Cicilass

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2008 03:37PM southernchick wrote: I'm glad your surgery is over and you are doing well.  Very glad u got the news that no lymph nodes were involved.  I had a bi-lateral mastectomy July 07.  I have never once regretted the decision.  I did have reconstruction, but haven't had my nipples done yet.  All you need to do now is rest and recuperate.  When the Dr. tells you to do the exercises...do them!!  I was bad about that and sometimes I wonder if the pain I have under my arms sometimes are because I didn't do them enough.    The most important thing for you to do now is get better.  Don't worry about the future, don't worry about how you'll look.  You are still here!!!!
Posts.Title: surgery scheduled for next Friday kaye45 southernchick

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2008 02:18PM southernchick wrote: Did they say why they wanted you to come back?  Maybe they didn't get good images for some reason.  Or maybe the technician didn't take enough angles for a baseline.  I'm sure it is nothing.  Good luck with the not worrying though.

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2008 04:31PM southernchick wrote: I think the vitamin E would be for her scars, but I don't think she would be able to use it in the hospital, it would be too soon.
Posts.Title: HELP...PLEASE...NEED ADVICE... nourtneybhorn BustersMom

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2008 09:30AM southernchick wrote: justkat, I am so sorry you are having to go through this.  But you have found a place where you can vent, talk, get support.  These boards helped me a lot this past year and a half.  No one wants to have to make these types of decisions.  If you talk to people about this, you will be given all kinds of unsolicited advice on what you should do.  But the decision is personal for each woman.  You have to do what you feel is right for you, regardless of anyone elses opinion. It is not an easy decision.  I had a terrible time making a decision for myself.  But once I made the decision, I felt like the weight of the world was lifted off my shoulders.  I have never looked back and never once regretted the decision I made.  Becase I made it not listening to anyone but myself and I know it was right for me.   Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: the other shoe... but there are three feet lol justkat justkat

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2008 03:09PM southernchick wrote: Hi.  I am 46 and had invasive breast cancer in one breast, diagnosed a year ago.  I had a lumpectomy without clean margins.  They went in two more times and still didn't get clean margins.  I had to have a mastectomy last July.  I had a very difficult time making the decision on doing one side or two.  But when I finally made the decision, it was like the weight of the world was gone.  I elected to do a bi-lateral mastectomy with reconstrucion.  I just felt like I had to do whatever I could to lower my chances of recurrence in the other breast. So many people that I have spoken with that opted for a unilateral, has gotten a recurrence on the other side.  I am very happy I made this decision.  I do not have to worry every day now about my other breast.  For me, a bi-lateral mastectomy was peace of mind.  As everyone else has said, this is a very personal decision that only you can make.  Only you know your personality and how much risk you can live with.  I, personally, am glad I went the route I did, no regrets.
